elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig001">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a): Projection of the structure of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> along [010]. Large light grey circles, Sc; small dark grey circles, K; small black circles, C; small white circles, O; smallest white circles, H. (b): Projection of the structure of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> along [100] showing the ScO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>KO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> chains along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis. Two potassium atoms without their coordination polyhedra are displayed to show the filling of the elliptic cross-section tunnels. Light grey polyhedra, ScO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>; dark grey polyhedra, KO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>; small black circles, C; small white circles, O; smallest white circles, H. Similar projection stands for isotypical oxalate <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr002"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a): Projection of the structure of I along [010]. Large light grey circles, Sc; small dark grey circles, K; small black circles, C; small white circles, O; smallest white circles, H. (b): Projection of the structure of I along [100] showing the ScO8 KO8 chains along b axis. Two potassium atoms without their coordination polyhedra are displayed to show the filling of the elliptic cross-section tunnels. Light grey polyhedra, ScO8; dark grey polyhedra, KO8; small black circles, C; small white circles, O; smallest white circles, H. Similar projection stands for isotypical oxalate II.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig003">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Representation of the scandium coordination antiprism in compound <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>. The O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O distances are indicated according to the common notation used by Hoard and Silverton <ce:cross-ref refid="bib040">[40]</ce:cross-ref>. The atomic-displacement ellipsoids are plotted at the 50% probability level. The indium environment in compound <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> is similar to that of scandium.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr004"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Representation of the scandium coordination antiprism in compound I. The OO distances are indicated according to the common notation used by Hoard and Silverton [40]. The atomic-displacement ellipsoids are plotted at the 50% probability level. The indium environment in compound II is similar to that of scandium.

The inset displays the TG curve for heating to 165 °C and cooling until 20 °C (5 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig009">
<ce:label>Fig. 9</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Drawings of metal-bischelating oxalate chains and anionic open-frameworks of two families of oxalates based on antiprisms or dodecahedra. <ce:italic>M</ce:italic> and <mml:math altimg="si78.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msup>
<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>
<mml:mo>′</mml:mo>
</mml:msup>
</mml:math> denote the cations of the frameworks and <mml:math altimg="si79.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msup>
<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>
<mml:mo>″</mml:mo>
</mml:msup>
</mml:math> denotes the counter-cations. Helical isotypic frameworks of the present family: (a) metal-antiprisms helical-shaped chain; (b) projection of the open-framework along [010] (the same projection stands also along [100] and [110]) showing elliptic and square cross-section tunnels. Isotypic-frameworks of previously reported family: (c) metal-dodecahedra zig-zag chain; (d) projection of the open-framework along [111] showing only elliptic cross-section tunnels. The circles denote the crystallographic sites occupied by counter-cations and/or water molecules. The arrows represent the direction of connection of metal polyhedra.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr010"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 9  Drawings of metal-bischelating oxalate chains and anionic open-frameworks of two families of oxalates based on antiprisms or dodecahedra. M and   M '   denote the cations of the frameworks and   M "   denotes the counter-cations. Helical isotypic frameworks of the present family: (a) metal-antiprisms helical-shaped chain; (b) projection of the open-framework along [010] (the same projection stands also along [100] and [110]) showing elliptic and square cross-section tunnels. Isotypic-frameworks of previously reported family: (c) metal-dodecahedra zig-zag chain; (d) projection of the open-framework along [111] showing only elliptic cross-section tunnels. The circles denote the crystallographic sites occupied by counter-cations and/or water molecules. The arrows represent the direction of connection of metal polyhedra.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new mixed oxalates with an open architecture, ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (I) and InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) (II), have been synthesised from precipitation methods at ambient temperature. They crystallize in hexagonal system, space group  P  6 2  22  (No. 180),  Z = 3 , with the following unit-cell parameters for I:  a = 8.8667 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 11.4908 ( 4 )   Å ,  V = 782.36 ( 4 )    Å 3  , for II:  a = 9.0148 ( 3 )   Å ,  c = 11.4645 ( 3 )   Å ,  V = 806.86 ( 4 )    Å 3  . The two structures belong to a family of isotypic helical anionic open-frameworks built from square antiprismatic coordinated metals and bischelating oxalates. The counter-cations K+ and Rb+/H3O+ are located in the tunnels of the framework. The thermal decomposition process has demonstrated zeolite-like properties associated with weakly-bonded water molecules located in the voids of the framework.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract



Introduction

The area of inorganic open-framework materials has become a field of increasing interest in recent years in order to discover new types of porous solids with potential zeolite-like properties. Furthermore, there is an intense activity on the design of new open architectures with various topologies on the basis of the concepts of building unit, scale chemistry and interconnected networks (see, for example, Refs. ), recently enhanced by computational structure prediction . The activity in the elaboration of new hybrid materials with organic linkers such as carboxylate-based metal materials has been intense . Indeed, metal carboxylates are robust enough to show permanent porosity with sometimes giant apparent surface areas  and can also be useful for selective sorption and separation processes, exchange properties, catalytic applications or gas and nanomaterials storage , . Among carboxylate ligands, oxalate anion is a main linker because of its relatively low cost useful for further industrial applications, its great solubility in many solvents comparing to other carboxylates allowing simple preparation, and its relatively thermal robustness. Additionally, the structure topology is often favourable to dynamic properties due to the zeolite-like storage of water molecules inside tunnels of the structures . Representative recent examples have been reported for a series of mixed oxalates with crystal structures consisting of isotypic anionic frameworks [ M  M '  (C2O4)4]2- built from dodecahedrally coordinated M and   M '   metals and counter-cations located in tunnels . Zeolite-like properties have been evidenced and a predictive structural derivation has been presented . For mixed oxalates containing MO8 polyhedra with square-antiprismatic geometries, another 3D open-framework topology is generated . Mixed indium oxalates InNH4(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and InNa(C2O4)2⋅2H2O have also been reported  and can be included in the family described in the present work. Some of these oxalates exhibit dynamic disorder associated to the mobility of the counter-cations located in the tunnels . Examples of open-framework materials involving Sc atoms were reported for scandium phosphates , phosphonate  and recently a 3D scandium terephtalate with hydrogen sorption properties . The new oxalate ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 is the first scandium oxalate with a 3D open architecture. The present study deals with a generalisation of the crystal chemistry of the oxalate family built from antiprisms supported by the description of the crystal structures and thermal behaviours of two new members ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 and InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O).

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and preliminary characterisation</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All chemicals were commercially available and used as received. Crystals of the mixed oxalates ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>), InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>) and InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>) were obtained by soft chemistry routes. The mixed scandium potassium oxalate ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was prepared from a mixture of Sc(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>⋅<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.4 g) and KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.17 g), dissolved in 25 mL of distilled water. A solution of oxalic acid (0.5 mol L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) was subsequently added in excess until the formation of a white precipitate. The mixture was then heated up to 60 °C and about 10 mL of concentrated HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> were slowly added until complete dissolution. The evaporation of the solution at room temperature led to the formation of hexagonal-shaped transparent crystals after about twenty hours. Long ago Štěrba-Böhm and Škramovský  prepared mixed oxalates with the suggested formulae ScNH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and reported the hexagonal shape of the monocrystals. The mixed indium rubidium oxalate InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) was prepared from the addition of InCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.1 g), RbNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.13 g) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.11 g) to 30 mL of distilled water. The fine white precipitate that forms was completely dissolved by heating the mixture at 50 °C under stirring during five minutes. Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after about twenty hours. The mixed oxalate InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>) has also been prepared in this work. Single crystals were obtained from the slow evaporation of a water solution (25 mL) containing indium chloride (0.1 g), caesium nitrate (0.18 g) and oxalic acid (0.14 g). Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after one day. One can notice that Deichman  prepared also mixed indium caesium oxalate and suggested that it is isomorphous to mixed indium and ammonium oxalate by comparison of X-ray photographs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis and preliminary characterisation

All chemicals were commercially available and used as received. Crystals of the mixed oxalates ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (I), InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) (II) and InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (III) were obtained by soft chemistry routes. The mixed scandium potassium oxalate ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 was prepared from a mixture of Sc(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.4 g) and KNO3 (0.17 g), dissolved in 25 mL of distilled water. A solution of oxalic acid (0.5 molL-1) was subsequently added in excess until the formation of a white precipitate. The mixture was then heated up to 60°C and about 10 mL of concentrated HNO3 were slowly added until complete dissolution. The evaporation of the solution at room temperature led to the formation of hexagonal-shaped transparent crystals after about twenty hours. Long ago Štěrba-Böhm and Škramovský  prepared mixed oxalates with the suggested formulae ScNH4(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and ScK(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and reported the hexagonal shape of the monocrystals. The mixed indium rubidium oxalate InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) was prepared from the addition of InCl3 (0.1 g), RbNO3 (0.13 g) and H2C2O4⋅2H2O (0.11 g) to 30 mL of distilled water. The fine white precipitate that forms was completely dissolved by heating the mixture at 50°C under stirring during five minutes. Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after about twenty hours. The mixed oxalate InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (III) has also been prepared in this work. Single crystals were obtained from the slow evaporation of a water solution (25 mL) containing indium chloride (0.1 g), caesium nitrate (0.18 g) and oxalic acid (0.14 g). Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after one day. One can notice that Deichman  prepared also mixed indium caesium oxalate and suggested that it is isomorphous to mixed indium and ammonium oxalate by comparison of X-ray photographs.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">X-ray diffraction patterns of the powdered crystals (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>), collected by means of a Siemens D500 diffractometer, indicated that the products were pure and that their crystal structures present strong relationships. The proposed chemical formulae are ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) and InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The formulations were derived from energy dispersive analyses performed on single-crystals with a JSM 6400 spectrometer, equipped with an Oxford Link Isis analyzer with a VARIAN SpectrAA 10 plus, and from the crystal structure determinations reported hereunder for oxalates <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, and thermogravimetry for oxalate <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>. The mean ratios Sc<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>:<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>K, In<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>:<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>Rb and In<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>:<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>Cs, that were found from five energy dispersive spectroscopy analyses, are 1.0, 1.2 and 1.0, respectively. For oxalate <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, due to the low quality of the crystals only the unit-cell parameters have been determined.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: X-ray diffraction patterns of the powdered crystals (I, II, III), collected by means of a Siemens D500 diffractometer, indicated that the products were pure and that their crystal structures present strong relationships. The proposed chemical formulae are ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2, InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) and InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2. The formulations were derived from energy dispersive analyses performed on single-crystals with a JSM 6400 spectrometer, equipped with an Oxford Link Isis analyzer with a VARIAN SpectrAA 10 plus, and from the crystal structure determinations reported hereunder for oxalates I and II, and thermogravimetry for oxalate III. The mean ratios Sc:K, In:Rb and In:Cs, that were found from five energy dispersive spectroscopy analyses, are 1.0, 1.2 and 1.0, respectively. For oxalate III, due to the low quality of the crystals only the unit-cell parameters have been determined.

elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal data collection

Suitable single-crystals of I and II were mounted on a four-circle Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer, using Mo  K α   radiation ( λ = 0.71073   Å ) and equipped with a CCD area detector. Intensities were collected by means of the program COLLECT . Reflection indexing, Lorentz-polarisation correction, peak integration and background determination were carried out with the program DENZO of the KappaCCD software package . The unit-cell parameters were refined with the program SCALEPACK . Numerical absorption corrections were performed using the program ANALYTICAL  included in the WinGX program suite . The resulting set of hkl reflections were used for structure refinement. Crystallographic data and details on data collection and refinement are listed in  . Structure drawings were carried out with Diamond 3.0e, supplied by Crystal Impact .

</mml:msub>
</mml:math>), equipped with an Anton Paar HTK1200 oven camera. For pattern indexing, the extraction of the peak positions was carried out with the Socabim program PROFILE, which is a part of the DIFFRACT-AT software package supplied by Bruker AXS. Pattern indexing was performed with the program DICVOL04 . The unit-cell parameters have been subsequently refined using NBS*AIDS .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Collection of X-ray powder diffraction data

X-ray powder diffraction data were obtained with a Siemens D500 diffractometer with the parafocusing Bragg-Brentano geometry, using monochromatic Cu  K  α 1    radiation ( λ = 1.5406   Å ) selected with an incident beam curved-crystal germanium monochromator . Additional powder diffraction data were collected in situ at different temperatures, with a Bruker AXS D5005 powder diffractometer using a diffracted-beam-graphite monochromator (Cu  K  α  1 , 2    ), equipped with an Anton Paar HTK1200 oven camera. For pattern indexing, the extraction of the peak positions was carried out with the Socabim program PROFILE, which is a part of the DIFFRACT-AT software package supplied by Bruker AXS. Pattern indexing was performed with the program DICVOL04 . The unit-cell parameters have been subsequently refined using NBS*AIDS .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Temperature-dependent X-ray diffraction (TDXD) was performed under flowing air with a powder diffractometer equipped with a curved-position-sensitive detector (INEL CPS 120) and a high-temperature attachment from Rigaku. The detector was used in a semi-focusing arrangement by reflection (Cu <mml:math altimg="si25.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msub>
<mml:mi>K</mml:mi>
<mml:msub>
<mml:mi>α</mml:mi>
<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>
</mml:msub>
</mml:msub>
</mml:math> radiation) as described elsewhere . With this geometry, the stationary sample is deposited on a flat sample holder located at the centre of the goniometer. An angle of 6° was selected between the incident beam and the surface of the sample. To ensure satisfactory counting statistics, counting times of 3600 and 3000 s/pattern were selected for the thermal decompositions of oxalates <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, respectively. Decompositions were carried out in flowing air with a heating rate of 5 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> between 20 and 450/350 °C and 25 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in the range 450–600/350–600 °C for oxalates <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>/<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, respectively. Temperature calibration was carried out with standard materials in the involved temperature range.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Temperature-dependent X-ray diffraction (TDXD) was performed under flowing air with a powder diffractometer equipped with a curved-position-sensitive detector (INEL CPS 120) and a high-temperature attachment from Rigaku. The detector was used in a semi-focusing arrangement by reflection (Cu  K  α 1    radiation) as described elsewhere . With this geometry, the stationary sample is deposited on a flat sample holder located at the centre of the goniometer. An angle of 6° was selected between the incident beam and the surface of the sample. To ensure satisfactory counting statistics, counting times of 3600 and 3000 s/pattern were selected for the thermal decompositions of oxalates I and II, respectively. Decompositions were carried out in flowing air with a heating rate of 5°Ch-1 between 20 and 450/350°C and 25°Ch-1 in the range 450-600/350-600°C for oxalates I/II, respectively. Temperature calibration was carried out with standard materials in the involved temperature range.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermal analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements were performed with a Rigaku Thermoflex instrument in flowing air. The powdered samples were spread evenly in large platinum crucibles to avoid mass effects. The TG measurements were carried out with a heating rate of 5 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> between 20 and 450/350 °C and 25 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in the range 450–900/350–900 °C for oxalates <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>/<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis

Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements were performed with a Rigaku Thermoflex instrument in flowing air. The powdered samples were spread evenly in large platinum crucibles to avoid mass effects. The TG measurements were carried out with a heating rate of 5°Ch-1 between 20 and 450/350°C and 25°Ch-1 in the range 450-900/350-900°C for oxalates I/II.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structures resolution of oxalates I and II 

The structures have been solved in a hexagonal unit-cell with space group  P  6 2  22  (No. 180). The heavy atoms were located using the direct methods and Patterson function with the programs SHELXS-97  and SIR97  available in the WinGX software package . The remaining non-H atoms, and also the H atoms in ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2, were localised from successive difference Fourier maps with SHELXL-97 . In the case of II, once all the atoms were localized leading to the formula InRb(C2O4)2(H2O)2, the maximum residual density peak was 6.62 eÅ-1. Supplementary low temperature (263 K) X-ray diffraction data were collected but the residual density peaks remained too weak. Consequently, the refinement of the structure was performed by introducing a statistical disorder to take into account the residual density. Rb and O atoms were constrained to occupy statistically two sites denoted M1 and M2, which correspond to the sites occupied by K and H2O in the Sc/K oxalate ( ). The deduced ratio In:Rb (1.3) agrees well with the one calculated from the EDS analysis. However, the number of metal atoms determined does not counterbalance the anionic charge of the oxalate anions. Since no other heavy atom was detected by EDS, the presence of H3O+ ions was suggested in agreement with the acidic solution used for the preparation. It was not possible to find positions of the H atoms. Consequently, the O atoms localised at M1 or M2 sites (3a and 6h Wyckoff notations) belong to water molecules or hydronium ions. Furthermore, the 6f site is also occupied by 0.5 water molecule per unit-cell () leading to the proposed chemical formula InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O). One can notice that disorder was also reported for the related oxalate CdZrCs1.5(H3O)0.5(C2O4)4⋅xH2O . In the latter case, the phenomenon was supposed to be associated with cationic exchange properties.

<ce:para view="all">For <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, all atoms were included in the final least-squares refinement and in the case of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> restraints were applied to O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H distances [0.96(1) Å] and H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H distances [1.52(1) Å] according to the geometry of the water molecule. The last cycles of refinement included atomic coordinates for all atoms and anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-H atoms (except Ow atom in <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>). Solvent accessible voids have been calculated by means of the program SOLV included in the software PLATON . The final atomic coordinates together with their equivalent isotropic displacement parameters are listed in . The main bond distances are reported in

elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structures

The diffraction lines of the powder patterns of ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2, InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) and InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 have been indexed with high figures of merit in hexagonal system. The resulting refined zero-point shift is 0.05° (2θ) for I and the refined unit-cell parameters are:  a = 8.8646 ( 3 )   Å ,  c = 11.4714 ( 6 )   Å ,  V = 780.67 ( 5 )    Å 3   with figures of merit M20 = 74 and F30 = 124(0.0062, 39). For II, the refined zero-point shift is 0.036° (2θ) and the refined unit-cell parameters are:  a = 9.0122 ( 3 )   Å ,  c = 11.4437 ( 6 )   Å ,  V = 804.93 ( 6 )    Å 3   with figures of merit M20 = 93, F30 = 139(0.0065, 33). The resulting refined zero-point shift is 0.04° (2θ) for III and the refined unit-cell parameters are:  a = 9.2129 ( 4 )   Å ,  c = 11.080 ( 1 )   Å ,  V = 814.48 ( 8 )    Å 3   with figures of merit M20 = 125 and F30 = 114(0.0056, 47). The powder data have been submitted to the ICDD  for possible inclusion in the Powder Diffraction File. It was subsequently verified that the powder patterns were in agreement with the patterns calculated from the single-crystal structure determinations for compounds I and II.

The anionic frameworks are built from <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> polyhedra linked through oxalate bischelating groups. The structures are isotypical to those of InNH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and InNa(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and also show similarities with those already thoroughly described for mixed oxalates CdZr(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅3.9H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, CdZr(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅4.4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , CdZrNa<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅ 8.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and CdZrCs<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . Indeed the eight-fold metal atoms Sc and In and the oxalate groups arrange themselves into interconnected helical chains (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig001"></ce:float-anchor>(a)) as described in detail in Ref. . These right-hand helices consist of <ce:italic>M</ce:italic> atoms linked through the oxalate groups in the form of (-<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>-ox-)<ce:inf loc="post">∝</ce:inf> chains along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. The total volumes within the anionic frameworks available for guest water molecules and K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> or Rb<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations correspond to 45.6 and 46.9% of the total unit-cell volume for compounds <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, respectively. The coordination polyhedra of both scandium and indium atoms (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig003"></ce:float-anchor>) can be described as slightly distorted square antiprisms similar to those found, for In in InNH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and InNa(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and for Cd and Zr atoms in the related oxalates . The two edge lengths <ce:italic>l</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>s</ce:italic> are reported in , according to Hoard and Silverton's formalism . While the eight <ce:italic>s</ce:italic> distances are fairly equivalent, the <ce:italic>l</ce:italic> values show a discrepancy with three different values. This feature is linked to the distortion of the polyhedra with a tilt angle of ∼38° between the two bases, instead of the 45° angle found in the ideal square-based antiprism, to fit in with the periods of the helices, as already reported for CdZrNa<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅8.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . The mean planes of the square bases have 0.06° and 0.03° maximum atomic deviations from planarity for ScO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> and InO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>, respectively. Moreover, these bases are nearly parallel with 0.63° and 0.35° angles between the two mean planes for ScO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> and InO<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>. The mean Sc<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O [2.25(7) Å] and In<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O [2.28(7) Å] distances are close to the theoretical values calculated with the bond valence method  for eight-fold coordinated scandium and indium atoms (2.212/2.265 Å). It is worth noting that such a polyhedron is not frequent for Sc, and was only encountered, to the best of our knowledge, in ScVO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
, ScPO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
 and Sc<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>⋅6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . Usually, Sc atom is surrounded by six oxygen atoms forming an octahedron as in phosphate- , phosphonate-  and carboxylate-based  structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The two oxalates I and II display three-dimensional [  M 2  (C2O4)4]2- ( M = Sc , In ) anionic frameworks whose charge is balanced by inserted counter-cations (K+ or Rb+/H3O+). The anionic frameworks are built from MO8 polyhedra linked through oxalate bischelating groups. The structures are isotypical to those of InNH4(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and InNa(C2O4)2⋅2H2O  and also show similarities with those already thoroughly described for mixed oxalates CdZr(NH4)2(C2O4)4⋅3.9H2O, CdZr(C2H10N2)2(C2O4)4⋅4.4H2O , CdZrNa2(C2O4)4⋅ 8.5H2O  and CdZrCs1.5(H3O)0.5(C2O4)4⋅nH2O . Indeed the eight-fold metal atoms Sc and In and the oxalate groups arrange themselves into interconnected helical chains ( (a)) as described in detail in Ref. . These right-hand helices consist of M atoms linked through the oxalate groups in the form of (-M-ox-)∝ chains along the c axis. They display tunnels with a hexagonal cross-section along c (I:  ∅ ~ 5.5   Å ; II:  ∅ ~ 5.6   Å ) ( ) and with elliptic (I:  ~ 5.5 × 9.0   Å ; II:  5.6 × 8.3   Å ) and square (I: ~6.5 Å; II: 6.6 Å) cross-sections along a, b and [110] (). The total volumes within the anionic frameworks available for guest water molecules and K+ or Rb+/H3O+ cations correspond to 45.6 and 46.9% of the total unit-cell volume for compounds I and II, respectively. The coordination polyhedra of both scandium and indium atoms ( ) can be described as slightly distorted square antiprisms similar to those found, for In in InNH4(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and InNa(C2O4)2⋅2H2O  and for Cd and Zr atoms in the related oxalates . The two edge lengths l and s are reported in , according to Hoard and Silverton's formalism . While the eight s distances are fairly equivalent, the l values show a discrepancy with three different values. This feature is linked to the distortion of the polyhedra with a tilt angle of ~38° between the two bases, instead of the 45° angle found in the ideal square-based antiprism, to fit in with the periods of the helices, as already reported for CdZrNa2(C2O4)4⋅8.5H2O . The mean planes of the square bases have 0.06° and 0.03° maximum atomic deviations from planarity for ScO8 and InO8, respectively. Moreover, these bases are nearly parallel with 0.63° and 0.35° angles between the two mean planes for ScO8 and InO8. The mean ScO [2.25(7) Å] and InO [2.28(7) Å] distances are close to the theoretical values calculated with the bond valence method  for eight-fold coordinated scandium and indium atoms (2.212/2.265 Å). It is worth noting that such a polyhedron is not frequent for Sc, and was only encountered, to the best of our knowledge, in ScVO4 , ScPO4  and Sc2(C2O4)3⋅6H2O . Usually, Sc atom is surrounded by six oxygen atoms forming an octahedron as in phosphate- , phosphonate-  and carboxylate-based  structures.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">There is only one crystallographic chelating oxalate group in both structure, which spans half of the <ce:italic>s</ce:italic> edges of scandium or indium polyhedra (). The oxalate anion acts as a bischelating ligand towards scandium or indium atoms, but also as a monodentate ligand towards cations K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and Rb<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>. The bond distances and angles within the oxalate groups are listed in . They are in good agreement with the mean values reported by Hahn  for oxalate-based compounds. The oxalate groups are nearly planar with mean atomic deviations from the least-square plane of 0.06 Å and 0.03 Å for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: There is only one crystallographic chelating oxalate group in both structure, which spans half of the s edges of scandium or indium polyhedra (). The oxalate anion acts as a bischelating ligand towards scandium or indium atoms, but also as a monodentate ligand towards cations K+ and Rb+. The bond distances and angles within the oxalate groups are listed in . They are in good agreement with the mean values reported by Hahn  for oxalate-based compounds. The oxalate groups are nearly planar with mean atomic deviations from the least-square plane of 0.06 Å and 0.03 Å for I and II, respectively.

The coordination polyhedron of Rb<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> is not defined as that of Cs<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> in the related non-stoichiometric oxalate CdZrCs<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . In <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> the additional 0.5 water molecule is located in the square-cross sections along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> and [110] ((b)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The counter-cations K+ and Rb+/H3O+ are located in the tunnels with elliptic cross-section ((b)) or hexagonal cross sections (). The distance between two successive cations is  c / 3  Å along the c axis. In I, the cation K+ is surrounded by four oxygen atoms belonging to oxalate groups and four water molecules forming a dodecahedral polyhedron ( ). All the water molecules are in the environment of the counter-cation leading to the chemical formula ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2. Even if it was not mentioned by the authors, the Na+ cation has also a dodecahedral polyhedron in InNa(C2O4)2⋅2H2O . The distances within the dodecahedron are reported in , using the formalism introduced by Hoard and Silverton . The analysis of the distances with this notation shows that the environment is close to an ideal   D  2 d    dodecahedron with six groups of distances M  A, M  B, a, b, m and g (). The shortest metal to oxygen distances involve oxygen atoms from water molecules whereas the four longer distances are those with oxygen atoms belonging to oxalate group. The average distances in the KO8 polyhedron are in good agreement with previously reported values in oxalates containing eight-fold coordinated K, e.g., YK(C2O4)2⋅4H2O , CdZrK2(C2O4)4⋅8H2O  and InK(C2O4)2⋅4H2O . Furthermore, the mean KO distance, i.e., 2.9(1) Å, agrees well with the theoretical value (2.901 Å) calculated with the bond valence method . The coordination polyhedron of Rb+ is not defined as that of Cs+ in the related non-stoichiometric oxalate CdZrCs1.5(H3O)0.5(C2O4)4⋅nH2O . In II the additional 0.5 water molecule is located in the square-cross sections along a, b and [110] ((b)).

The Sc and K polyhedra, possess a common edge, thus forming infinite chains along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis ((b)). This description stands also for the isotypic-framework InNa(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text: An alternative description of the structure of ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 can be proposed. The Sc and K polyhedra, possess a common edge, thus forming infinite chains along the b axis ((b)). The same feature is also observed along a axis and in [110] direction. This description stands also for the isotypic-framework InNa(C2O4)2(H2O)2  structure in which the environment of Na is also a dodecahedron.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In oxalates <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> the counter-cations K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> or Rb<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> possess larger thermal motion than those of the atoms Sc or In of the open-framework (). Furthermore in <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, the thermal ellipsoid of <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>1 and <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>2 are highly elongated along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. This feature suggests a mobility of the counter-cations inside the tunnels, although being less pronounced than the dynamic disorder observed in CdZrNa<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅8.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and CdZrCs<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In oxalates I and II the counter-cations K+ or Rb+/H3O+ possess larger thermal motion than those of the atoms Sc or In of the open-framework (). Furthermore in II, the thermal ellipsoid of M1 and M2 are highly elongated along the c axis. This feature suggests a mobility of the counter-cations inside the tunnels, although being less pronounced than the dynamic disorder observed in CdZrNa2(C2O4)4⋅8.5H2O  and CdZrCs1.5(H3O)0.5(C2O4)4⋅nH2O .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Thermal behaviour</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Thermal decomposition of ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The thermal decomposition of ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can be described in a four-step process according to the TG curve (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig005"></ce:float-anchor>) and the TDXD analysis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig006"></ce:float-anchor>) recorded under flowing air. The chemical formula deduced from the TG curve is ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at room temperature. The dehydration of the precursor occurs into two steps. The TG curve clearly shows that the precursor is stable until ∼100 °C, where the material starts losing weight and undergoes an important structural change. Indeed, the TDXD plot shows that a new crystalline phase is formed at ∼125 °C and is stable up to ∼155 °C. According to the TG analysis, this intermediate phase would correspond to ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> with a measured weight loss of 9.0% (theoretical 9.1%). Then, between ∼155 and ∼165 °C, another structural change is observed in the TDXD plot. It coincides with a second weight loss (12.4%) in the TG curve, which agrees well with the departure of the last half water molecule (theoretical: 12.17%). One can notice that InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> displays a similar behaviour.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal behaviour

Thermal decomposition of ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 

The thermal decomposition of ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 can be described in a four-step process according to the TG curve ( ) and the TDXD analysis ( ) recorded under flowing air. The chemical formula deduced from the TG curve is ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 at room temperature. The dehydration of the precursor occurs into two steps. The TG curve clearly shows that the precursor is stable until ~100°C, where the material starts losing weight and undergoes an important structural change. Indeed, the TDXD plot shows that a new crystalline phase is formed at ~125°C and is stable up to ~155°C. According to the TG analysis, this intermediate phase would correspond to ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)0.5 with a measured weight loss of 9.0% (theoretical 9.1%). Then, between ~155 and ~165°C, another structural change is observed in the TDXD plot. It coincides with a second weight loss (12.4%) in the TG curve, which agrees well with the departure of the last half water molecule (theoretical: 12.17%). One can notice that InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 displays a similar behaviour.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The dehydration is fully reversible as demonstrated by TG ( inset) experiment carried out in air upon heating to 165 °C and then cooling at room temperature. It was checked by TDXD that the crystal structure was preserved after the dehydration–rehydration process. Consequently, the water molecules located inside the structure framework possess a zeolite-like behaviour.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The dehydration is fully reversible as demonstrated by TG ( inset) experiment carried out in air upon heating to 165°C and then cooling at room temperature. It was checked by TDXD that the crystal structure was preserved after the dehydration-rehydration process. Consequently, the water molecules located inside the structure framework possess a zeolite-like behaviour.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">According to the TG curve, the anhydrous phase ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> decomposes between ∼265 and ∼370 °C. The observed weight-loss (52.6%) corresponds to the formation of the mixture of Sc<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (theoretical: 53.4%). The diffraction lines of nanocrystalline cubic Sc<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> appear around 370 °C whereas the TDXD plot does not show any diffraction lines corresponding to potassium carbonate. It can be supposed that K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is formed in an amorphous state. Such a feature has already been observed in the thermal decomposition of oxalate-based alkali metals, e.g., La(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>K(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , Y(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)Cs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
, CdZrK<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and InK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅4(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) . The potassium carbonate starts decomposing at 700 °C. The composition of the final oxide Sc<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is not fully reached at 900 °C. Furthermore, one can notice an inflexion point in the TG curve around 340 °C (weight loss: ∼50%) associated with a diffraction line at about 28.3° (2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>) in the TDXD plot in the temperature range 360–380 °C. This diffraction line could belong to Sc<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> since its position is close to those of related oxide carbonates Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> [PDF 2 No. 37-0806] and Gd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> [PDF2 No. 70-2152]. Furthermore, the weight-loss could suggest the global formula ‘ScKOCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>’ (theoretical: 45.9%). This hypothesis is supported by the formation of compounds with global formulae ‘YKOCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>’ and ‘InKOCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>’ during the decompositions of YK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅4(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)  and InK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅4(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) , respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: According to the TG curve, the anhydrous phase ScK(C2O4)2 decomposes between ~265 and ~370°C. The observed weight-loss (52.6%) corresponds to the formation of the mixture of Sc2O3 and K2CO3 (theoretical: 53.4%). The diffraction lines of nanocrystalline cubic Sc2O3 appear around 370°C whereas the TDXD plot does not show any diffraction lines corresponding to potassium carbonate. It can be supposed that K2CO3 is formed in an amorphous state. Such a feature has already been observed in the thermal decomposition of oxalate-based alkali metals, e.g., La(H2O)2K(C2O4)2⋅H2O , Y(H2O)Cs(C2O4)2 , CdZrK2(C2O4)4⋅8H2O  and InK(C2O4)2⋅4(H2O) . The potassium carbonate starts decomposing at 700°C. The composition of the final oxide Sc2O3 is not fully reached at 900°C. Furthermore, one can notice an inflexion point in the TG curve around 340°C (weight loss: ~50%) associated with a diffraction line at about 28.3° (2θ) in the TDXD plot in the temperature range 360-380°C. This diffraction line could belong to Sc2O2CO3 since its position is close to those of related oxide carbonates Nd2O2CO3 [PDF 2 No. 37-0806] and Gd2O2CO3 [PDF2 No. 70-2152]. Furthermore, the weight-loss could suggest the global formula ‘ScKOCO3' (theoretical: 45.9%). This hypothesis is supported by the formation of compounds with global formulae ‘YKOCO3' and ‘InKOCO3' during the decompositions of YK(C2O4)2⋅4(H2O)  and InK(C2O4)2⋅4(H2O) , respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Powder diffraction patterns of the hemihydrate ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> and the anhydrous ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> oxalates were recorded in situ under static air respectively at 140 and 270 °C. Unfortunately, the diffraction patterns could not be indexed because of the low crystallinity of the products.

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig007"></ce:float-anchor>). The metal content in the powder sample used for the TG analysis has been checked by EDS measurement (<mml:math altimg="si59.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mi mathvariant="normal">In</mml:mi>

<mml:mo>=</mml:mo>

</mml:math>). The chemical formula deduced from the crystal structure refinement InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) is in a good agreement with the observed successive weight losses. A first weight-loss is observed in the temperature range 90–125 °C (8.0%) and could correspond to the formation of the hemihydrate InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> (theoretical: 8.9%) but there is no well defined plateau. The thermodiffractometry recorded in air (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig008"></ce:float-anchor>a) shows that the precursor is stable until 100 °C where a structural changes occurs. The diffraction lines of the hemihydrate oxalate are observed until ∼155 °C. Subsequent thermogravimetry and thermodiffractometry experiments ((b)) carried out in air upon heating until 130 °C and then cooling at room temperature demonstrated that the dehydration is reversible and that the crystal structure is preserved after the dehydration–rehydration process. The composition of the anhydrous oxalate (11.09%) is reached at about 200 °C. Thermodiffractometry in the temperature range 155–215 °C shows that anhydrous oxalate is very poorly crystallised. The inflexion point in the TG curve at ∼220 °C (17.5%) agrees with the partial decomposition of the oxalate groups leading to the global formula InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (theoretical: 18.0%). Then the oxalate group is totally decomposed at 260 °C and a small plateau is observed until ∼290 °C (36.5%) suggesting the formation of the mixture In<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)–0.77Rb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (theoretical: 38.5%). The plateau between 325 and 675 °C (39.6%) corresponds to the formation of the mixture In<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–0.77Rb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (theoretical: 43.9%). Diffraction lines of cubic In<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> [PDF 2 No. 44-1087] appear at about 280 °C whereas those of the rubidium carbonate are not present demonstrating that it is amorphous. Contrary to potassium carbonate in previous decomposition, the rubidium carbonate (monoclinic polymorph) crystallises upon heating and the diffraction lines [PDF 2 No. 71-1980] appear around 325 °C ((a)). Finally the rubidium carbonate sublimates and the final weight-loss corresponds to the formation of the oxide In<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (obs.: 66.0%; theor.: 65.8%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal decomposition of InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O)

The thermal decomposition of the indium rubidium oxalate can be described as a five step process according to the TG curve recorded under flowing air ( ). The metal content in the powder sample used for the TG analysis has been checked by EDS measurement ( In : Rb = 1.2 ). The chemical formula deduced from the crystal structure refinement InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) is in a good agreement with the observed successive weight losses. A first weight-loss is observed in the temperature range 90-125°C (8.0%) and could correspond to the formation of the hemihydrate InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)0.5 (theoretical: 8.9%) but there is no well defined plateau. The thermodiffractometry recorded in air ( a) shows that the precursor is stable until 100°C where a structural changes occurs. The diffraction lines of the hemihydrate oxalate are observed until ~155°C. Subsequent thermogravimetry and thermodiffractometry experiments ((b)) carried out in air upon heating until 130°C and then cooling at room temperature demonstrated that the dehydration is reversible and that the crystal structure is preserved after the dehydration-rehydration process. The composition of the anhydrous oxalate (11.09%) is reached at about 200°C. Thermodiffractometry in the temperature range 155-215°C shows that anhydrous oxalate is very poorly crystallised. The inflexion point in the TG curve at ~220°C (17.5%) agrees with the partial decomposition of the oxalate groups leading to the global formula InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)(CO3) (theoretical: 18.0%). Then the oxalate group is totally decomposed at 260°C and a small plateau is observed until ~290°C (36.5%) suggesting the formation of the mixture In2O2(CO3)-0.77Rb2CO3 (theoretical: 38.5%). The plateau between 325 and 675°C (39.6%) corresponds to the formation of the mixture In2O3-0.77Rb2CO3 (theoretical: 43.9%). Diffraction lines of cubic In2O3 [PDF 2 No. 44-1087] appear at about 280°C whereas those of the rubidium carbonate are not present demonstrating that it is amorphous. Contrary to potassium carbonate in previous decomposition, the rubidium carbonate (monoclinic polymorph) crystallises upon heating and the diffraction lines [PDF 2 No. 71-1980] appear around 325°C ((a)). Finally the rubidium carbonate sublimates and the final weight-loss corresponds to the formation of the oxide In2O3 (obs.: 66.0%; theor.: 65.8%).

elements.clean_text:
Isotypic open-framework structures and comparison with a family with another topology

Known oxalates with helical-framework structures are listed in  . As in the family of isotypic open-frameworks based on dodecahedrally coordinated metals, the isotypic anionic frameworks based on antiprisms can be written as [ M  M '  (C2O4)4]2-. They also obey to the empirical valence rule standing that the sum of the valences of the two metals M and   M '   involved in the anionic framework is six, as first proposed for the previous family . Counter-cations denoted   M "   located in the tunnels compensate the charge leading to the general formula    [ M  M '    (  C 2   O 4  )  4  ]   2 +     (  M y "  )   2 +   ⋅ ( 4 + x )  H 2  O  (y is 2 for   M  "  +    metals and 1 for   M  "  2 +   ). Furthermore, oxalates with helical-framework structures possess weakly-bonded water molecules located in the tunnels of the framework, leading to zeolite-like properties.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">A most interesting comparison between the two open-framework structure families, based on antiprisms or dodecahedra , arises from the description of the crystal structure considering the tunnels instead of the polyhedra. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig009"></ce:float-anchor> depicts two projections of the open-framework structures, in [010] direction (it stands also for [100] and [110] directions) and in [111] direction for the frameworks based on antiprisms and dodecahedra, respectively. Both topologies result in chains (right-hand helices of period <ce:italic>P</ce:italic> or zig-zag chains) built from polyhedra (antiprisms or dodecahedra) connected by bischelating oxalate groups. Similar elliptic cross-section tunnels are generated by both open-frameworks. Such tunnels are well-known for metal oxalates . In the case of the framework based on antiprisms, square cross-section tunnels also appear in the projection and can be obtained by rotating of 120° the elliptic cross-section tunnels ((b)). Consequently, the elliptic cross-section tunnels are piled up along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis whereas in the family based on dodecahedra, they can be piled up only by shifting one layer towards the bottom one ((d)). In both families, tunnels are filled by counter-cations which can be located on two distinct sites symbolized by circles in . The polyhedra around the counter-cations <mml:math altimg="si86.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msup>
<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>
<mml:mo>″</mml:mo>
</mml:msup>
</mml:math> share common vertices with <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (and <mml:math altimg="si87.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msup>
<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>
<mml:mo>′</mml:mo>
</mml:msup>
</mml:math>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>) polyhedra forming infinite chains ((b)). In both structure types, the direction of connection crosses the tunnels in the same way as shown by arrows in .</ce:para>

Both topologies result in chains (right-hand helices of period P or zig-zag chains) built from polyhedra (antiprisms or dodecahedra) connected by bischelating oxalate groups. Similar elliptic cross-section tunnels are generated by both open-frameworks. Such tunnels are well-known for metal oxalates . In the case of the framework based on antiprisms, square cross-section tunnels also appear in the projection and can be obtained by rotating of 120° the elliptic cross-section tunnels ((b)). Consequently, the elliptic cross-section tunnels are piled up along the c axis whereas in the family based on dodecahedra, they can be piled up only by shifting one layer towards the bottom one ((d)). In both families, tunnels are filled by counter-cations which can be located on two distinct sites symbolized by circles in . The polyhedra around the counter-cations   M "   share common vertices with MO8 (and   M '  O8) polyhedra forming infinite chains ((b)). In both structure types, the direction of connection crosses the tunnels in the same way as shown by arrows in .

elements.clean_text: One could think that alkaline play a role, as a templated framework, in the formation of the helical structure . In fact, the chemical nature of the counter-cation cannot alone explain the topology of the open-framework. For instance, with K+, Rb+ and   NH 4   +  , mixed oxalates of the other family with framework based on dodecahedra are also formed . The comparison of ionic radii of metals M,   M '   on one hand and   M "   on the other hand can not justify the topology. Further investigations could be carried out by taking into account energetic considerations in order to compare the stability of the frameworks.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The present study has clearly demonstrated that ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) are two new members of a family of mixed oxalates with isotypic helical frameworks. The related oxalate InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> has also been prepared and belongs to this family. elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The present study has clearly demonstrated that ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 and InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) are two new members of a family of mixed oxalates with isotypic helical frameworks. The related oxalate InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 has also been prepared and belongs to this family. The anionic architecture, based on bischelating oxalate and eight-coordinate metals in the form of antiprisms, can be written as [ M  M '  (C2O4)4]2-. Alkaline counter-cations are located into the interconnected tunnels of the framework. The open-framework has been compared to that, also written [ M  M '  (C2O4)4]2-, of related oxalates built from eight-coordinate metals in the form of dodecahedra. Both families are characterized by an empirical rule stating that the sum of the valences of the two metals M and   M '   constitutive of the frameworks is six. Future investigations could focus on the criteria guiding the topology. Thermal studies have evidenced zeolite-like properties due to the storage of weakly-bonded water molecules.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and preliminary characterisation</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All chemicals were commercially available and used as received. Crystals of the mixed oxalates ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>), InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>) and InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>) were obtained by soft chemistry routes. The mixed scandium potassium oxalate ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was prepared from a mixture of Sc(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>⋅<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.4 g) and KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.17 g), dissolved in 25 mL of distilled water. A solution of oxalic acid (0.5 mol L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) was subsequently added in excess until the formation of a white precipitate. The mixture was then heated up to 60 °C and about 10 mL of concentrated HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> were slowly added until complete dissolution. The evaporation of the solution at room temperature led to the formation of hexagonal-shaped transparent crystals after about twenty hours. Long ago Štěrba-Böhm and Škramovský  prepared mixed oxalates with the suggested formulae ScNH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and reported the hexagonal shape of the monocrystals. The mixed indium rubidium oxalate InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) was prepared from the addition of InCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.1 g), RbNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.13 g) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.11 g) to 30 mL of distilled water. The fine white precipitate that forms was completely dissolved by heating the mixture at 50 °C under stirring during five minutes. Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after about twenty hours. The mixed oxalate InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>) has also been prepared in this work. Single crystals were obtained from the slow evaporation of a water solution (25 mL) containing indium chloride (0.1 g), caesium nitrate (0.18 g) and oxalic acid (0.14 g). Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after one day. One can notice that Deichman  prepared also mixed indium caesium oxalate and suggested that it is isomorphous to mixed indium and ammonium oxalate by comparison of X-ray photographs.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis and preliminary characterisation

All chemicals were commercially available and used as received. Crystals of the mixed oxalates ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (I), InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) (II) and InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (III) were obtained by soft chemistry routes. The mixed scandium potassium oxalate ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 was prepared from a mixture of Sc(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.4 g) and KNO3 (0.17 g), dissolved in 25 mL of distilled water. A solution of oxalic acid (0.5 molL-1) was subsequently added in excess until the formation of a white precipitate. The mixture was then heated up to 60°C and about 10 mL of concentrated HNO3 were slowly added until complete dissolution. The evaporation of the solution at room temperature led to the formation of hexagonal-shaped transparent crystals after about twenty hours. Long ago Štěrba-Böhm and Škramovský  prepared mixed oxalates with the suggested formulae ScNH4(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and ScK(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and reported the hexagonal shape of the monocrystals. The mixed indium rubidium oxalate InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) was prepared from the addition of InCl3 (0.1 g), RbNO3 (0.13 g) and H2C2O4⋅2H2O (0.11 g) to 30 mL of distilled water. The fine white precipitate that forms was completely dissolved by heating the mixture at 50°C under stirring during five minutes. Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after about twenty hours. The mixed oxalate InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (III) has also been prepared in this work. Single crystals were obtained from the slow evaporation of a water solution (25 mL) containing indium chloride (0.1 g), caesium nitrate (0.18 g) and oxalic acid (0.14 g). Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after one day. One can notice that Deichman  prepared also mixed indium caesium oxalate and suggested that it is isomorphous to mixed indium and ammonium oxalate by comparison of X-ray photographs.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new mixed oxalates with an open architecture, ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (I) and InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) (II), have been synthesised from precipitation methods at ambient temperature. They crystallize in hexagonal system, space group  P  6 2  22  (No. 180),  Z = 3 , with the following unit-cell parameters for I:  a = 8.8667 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 11.4908 ( 4 )   Å ,  V = 782.36 ( 4 )    Å 3  , for II:  a = 9.0148 ( 3 )   Å ,  c = 11.4645 ( 3 )   Å ,  V = 806.86 ( 4 )    Å 3  . The two structures belong to a family of isotypic helical anionic open-frameworks built from square antiprismatic coordinated metals and bischelating oxalates. The counter-cations K+ and Rb+/H3O+ are located in the tunnels of the framework. The thermal decomposition process has demonstrated zeolite-like properties associated with weakly-bonded water molecules located in the voids of the framework.

Results and discussion

Structures resolution of oxalates I and II 

The structures have been solved in a hexagonal unit-cell with space group  P  6 2  22  (No. 180). The heavy atoms were located using the direct methods and Patterson function with the programs SHELXS-97  and SIR97  available in the WinGX software package . The remaining non-H atoms, and also the H atoms in ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2, were localised from successive difference Fourier maps with SHELXL-97 . In the case of II, once all the atoms were localized leading to the formula InRb(C2O4)2(H2O)2, the maximum residual density peak was 6.62 eÅ-1. Supplementary low temperature (263 K) X-ray diffraction data were collected but the residual density peaks remained too weak. Consequently, the refinement of the structure was performed by introducing a statistical disorder to take into account the residual density. Rb and O atoms were constrained to occupy statistically two sites denoted M1 and M2, which correspond to the sites occupied by K and H2O in the Sc/K oxalate ( ). The deduced ratio In:Rb (1.3) agrees well with the one calculated from the EDS analysis. However, the number of metal atoms determined does not counterbalance the anionic charge of the oxalate anions. Since no other heavy atom was detected by EDS, the presence of H3O+ ions was suggested in agreement with the acidic solution used for the preparation. It was not possible to find positions of the H atoms. Consequently, the O atoms localised at M1 or M2 sites (3a and 6h Wyckoff notations) belong to water molecules or hydronium ions. Furthermore, the 6f site is also occupied by 0.5 water molecule per unit-cell () leading to the proposed chemical formula InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O). One can notice that disorder was also reported for the related oxalate CdZrCs1.5(H3O)0.5(C2O4)4⋅xH2O . In the latter case, the phenomenon was supposed to be associated with cationic exchange properties.

Description of the crystal structures

The diffraction lines of the powder patterns of ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2, InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) and InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 have been indexed with high figures of merit in hexagonal system. The resulting refined zero-point shift is 0.05° (2θ) for I and the refined unit-cell parameters are:  a = 8.8646 ( 3 )   Å ,  c = 11.4714 ( 6 )   Å ,  V = 780.67 ( 5 )    Å 3   with figures of merit M20 = 74 and F30 = 124(0.0062, 39). For II, the refined zero-point shift is 0.036° (2θ) and the refined unit-cell parameters are:  a = 9.0122 ( 3 )   Å ,  c = 11.4437 ( 6 )   Å ,  V = 804.93 ( 6 )    Å 3   with figures of merit M20 = 93, F30 = 139(0.0065, 33). The resulting refined zero-point shift is 0.04° (2θ) for III and the refined unit-cell parameters are:  a = 9.2129 ( 4 )   Å ,  c = 11.080 ( 1 )   Å ,  V = 814.48 ( 8 )    Å 3   with figures of merit M20 = 125 and F30 = 114(0.0056, 47). The powder data have been submitted to the ICDD  for possible inclusion in the Powder Diffraction File. It was subsequently verified that the powder patterns were in agreement with the patterns calculated from the single-crystal structure determinations for compounds I and II.

cln_elements.clean_text: The two oxalates I and II display three-dimensional [  M 2  (C2O4)4]2- ( M = Sc , In ) anionic frameworks whose charge is balanced by inserted counter-cations (K+ or Rb+/H3O+). The anionic frameworks are built from MO8 polyhedra linked through oxalate bischelating groups. The structures are isotypical to those of InNH4(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and InNa(C2O4)2⋅2H2O  and also show similarities with those already thoroughly described for mixed oxalates CdZr(NH4)2(C2O4)4⋅3.9H2O, CdZr(C2H10N2)2(C2O4)4⋅4.4H2O , CdZrNa2(C2O4)4⋅ 8.5H2O  and CdZrCs1.5(H3O)0.5(C2O4)4⋅nH2O . Indeed the eight-fold metal atoms Sc and In and the oxalate groups arrange themselves into interconnected helical chains ( (a)) as described in detail in Ref. . These right-hand helices consist of M atoms linked through the oxalate groups in the form of (-M-ox-)∝ chains along the c axis. They display tunnels with a hexagonal cross-section along c (I:  ∅ ~ 5.5   Å ; II:  ∅ ~ 5.6   Å ) ( ) and with elliptic (I:  ~ 5.5 × 9.0   Å ; II:  5.6 × 8.3   Å ) and square (I: ~6.5 Å; II: 6.6 Å) cross-sections along a, b and [110] (). The total volumes within the anionic frameworks available for guest water molecules and K+ or Rb+/H3O+ cations correspond to 45.6 and 46.9% of the total unit-cell volume for compounds I and II, respectively. The coordination polyhedra of both scandium and indium atoms ( ) can be described as slightly distorted square antiprisms similar to those found, for In in InNH4(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and InNa(C2O4)2⋅2H2O  and for Cd and Zr atoms in the related oxalates . The two edge lengths l and s are reported in , according to Hoard and Silverton's formalism . While the eight s distances are fairly equivalent, the l values show a discrepancy with three different values. This feature is linked to the distortion of the polyhedra with a tilt angle of ~38° between the two bases, instead of the 45° angle found in the ideal square-based antiprism, to fit in with the periods of the helices, as already reported for CdZrNa2(C2O4)4⋅8.5H2O . The mean planes of the square bases have 0.06° and 0.03° maximum atomic deviations from planarity for ScO8 and InO8, respectively. Moreover, these bases are nearly parallel with 0.63° and 0.35° angles between the two mean planes for ScO8 and InO8. The mean ScO [2.25(7) Å] and InO [2.28(7) Å] distances are close to the theoretical values calculated with the bond valence method  for eight-fold coordinated scandium and indium atoms (2.212/2.265 Å). It is worth noting that such a polyhedron is not frequent for Sc, and was only encountered, to the best of our knowledge, in ScVO4 , ScPO4  and Sc2(C2O4)3⋅6H2O . Usually, Sc atom is surrounded by six oxygen atoms forming an octahedron as in phosphate- , phosphonate-  and carboxylate-based  structures.

The counter-cations K+ and Rb+/H3O+ are located in the tunnels with elliptic cross-section ((b)) or hexagonal cross sections (). The distance between two successive cations is  c / 3  Å along the c axis. In I, the cation K+ is surrounded by four oxygen atoms belonging to oxalate groups and four water molecules forming a dodecahedral polyhedron ( ). All the water molecules are in the environment of the counter-cation leading to the chemical formula ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2. Even if it was not mentioned by the authors, the Na+ cation has also a dodecahedral polyhedron in InNa(C2O4)2⋅2H2O . The distances within the dodecahedron are reported in , using the formalism introduced by Hoard and Silverton . The analysis of the distances with this notation shows that the environment is close to an ideal   D  2 d    dodecahedron with six groups of distances M  A, M  B, a, b, m and g (). The shortest metal to oxygen distances involve oxygen atoms from water molecules whereas the four longer distances are those with oxygen atoms belonging to oxalate group. The average distances in the KO8 polyhedron are in good agreement with previously reported values in oxalates containing eight-fold coordinated K, e.g., YK(C2O4)2⋅4H2O , CdZrK2(C2O4)4⋅8H2O  and InK(C2O4)2⋅4H2O . Furthermore, the mean KO distance, i.e., 2.9(1) Å, agrees well with the theoretical value (2.901 Å) calculated with the bond valence method . The coordination polyhedron of Rb+ is not defined as that of Cs+ in the related non-stoichiometric oxalate CdZrCs1.5(H3O)0.5(C2O4)4⋅nH2O . In II the additional 0.5 water molecule is located in the square-cross sections along a, b and [110] ((b)).

Thermal behaviour

Thermal decomposition of ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 

The thermal decomposition of ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 can be described in a four-step process according to the TG curve ( ) and the TDXD analysis ( ) recorded under flowing air. The chemical formula deduced from the TG curve is ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 at room temperature. The dehydration of the precursor occurs into two steps. The TG curve clearly shows that the precursor is stable until ~100°C, where the material starts losing weight and undergoes an important structural change. Indeed, the TDXD plot shows that a new crystalline phase is formed at ~125°C and is stable up to ~155°C. According to the TG analysis, this intermediate phase would correspond to ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)0.5 with a measured weight loss of 9.0% (theoretical 9.1%). Then, between ~155 and ~165°C, another structural change is observed in the TDXD plot. It coincides with a second weight loss (12.4%) in the TG curve, which agrees well with the departure of the last half water molecule (theoretical: 12.17%). One can notice that InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 displays a similar behaviour.

According to the TG curve, the anhydrous phase ScK(C2O4)2 decomposes between ~265 and ~370°C. The observed weight-loss (52.6%) corresponds to the formation of the mixture of Sc2O3 and K2CO3 (theoretical: 53.4%). The diffraction lines of nanocrystalline cubic Sc2O3 appear around 370°C whereas the TDXD plot does not show any diffraction lines corresponding to potassium carbonate. It can be supposed that K2CO3 is formed in an amorphous state. Such a feature has already been observed in the thermal decomposition of oxalate-based alkali metals, e.g., La(H2O)2K(C2O4)2⋅H2O , Y(H2O)Cs(C2O4)2 , CdZrK2(C2O4)4⋅8H2O  and InK(C2O4)2⋅4(H2O) . The potassium carbonate starts decomposing at 700°C. The composition of the final oxide Sc2O3 is not fully reached at 900°C. Furthermore, one can notice an inflexion point in the TG curve around 340°C (weight loss: ~50%) associated with a diffraction line at about 28.3° (2θ) in the TDXD plot in the temperature range 360-380°C. This diffraction line could belong to Sc2O2CO3 since its position is close to those of related oxide carbonates Nd2O2CO3 [PDF 2 No. 37-0806] and Gd2O2CO3 [PDF2 No. 70-2152]. Furthermore, the weight-loss could suggest the global formula ‘ScKOCO3' (theoretical: 45.9%). This hypothesis is supported by the formation of compounds with global formulae ‘YKOCO3' and ‘InKOCO3' during the decompositions of YK(C2O4)2⋅4(H2O)  and InK(C2O4)2⋅4(H2O) , respectively.
